title: Christopher Eccleston had a 'wobble' after opening up on mental health
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Christopher Eccleston opened up on how being so open and honest about his mental health – including his struggles with a life-long eating disorder lead to a brief ‘wobble’.

Speaking to Lorraine Kelly this morning, the former Doctor Who actor opened up about how in talking so candidly about his experiences with anorexia and depression he compromised his mental health.

The star’s new book, titled I Love the Bones of You, chronicles his relationship with body image and his struggles with seeing his father suffer with dementia.

Chirstopher Eccleston opened up on how being so honest about his mental health in a new book caused a ‘wobble’ (Picture: ITV/REX)

‘I did have a wobble, a couple of weeks ago definitely,’ he told the Scottish presenter. ‘The pressure of [the book] and the exposure of talking about it in this way. What have I done, monetised my personal life? How has it affected my mum and dad?’

However, for Eccleston – who fronts The A-Word on BBC One – there was one thing to keep him focused and healthy – his children.

‘But I think, because I’m a parent, Albert and Esme keep me very focused,’ he shared. ‘It caused a bit of a wobble a couple of weeks ago with some of the issues that are in the book. The intensity and doing things like this, talking about it on television … there is a pressure there.’

The actor has previously opened up about living with an eating disorder (Picture: ITV/REX)

The Northern actor has in the past been equally honest about his professional and personal life; sharing the suicidal thoughts he had during his battle with anorexia or how he felt he gave a ‘dreadful performance’ in Thor: The Dark World.

The Ninth Doctor had also opened up about being ‘blacklisted’ from the BBC after he left the sci-fi show after just one series.

Lorraine airs weekdays from 8.30am on ITV.
